document.title:
L p
norms of trigonometric polynomials

para.p:
A trigonometric polynomial of degree
n
is an expression of the form

Math.text: list@(((sum _ (k = - n)) ^ n)@(c _ k * e ^ (i * k * t)), c _ k) element-of C

para.p:
Using the identity
=
e
⁢ i t
+
cos t
⁢ i
sin t
, we can write a trigonometric polynomial of degree
n
in the form

Math.text: list@(a _ 0 + ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(a _ k * cosine@(k * t)) + ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(b _ k * sine@(k * t)), a _ k, b _ k) element-of C

para.p:
For
1 ≤ p < ∞
and for a
⁢ 2 π
-periodic function
f
, we define the
L p
norm of
f
by

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ p = ((1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((absolute-value@(f * t)) ^ p * differential-d@(t))) ^ (1 / p)

para.p:
For a continuous
⁢ 2 π
-periodic function
f
, we define the
L ∞
norm of
f
by

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ infinity = (maximum _ (0 less= t less= 2 * pi))@(absolute-value@(f * t))

and

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ p = ((1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((absolute-value@(f * t)) ^ p * differential-d@(t))) ^ (1 / p) less= ((1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(((norm@(f)) _ infinity) ^ p * differential-d@(t))) ^ (1 / p) = (norm@(f)) _ infinity

para.p:
The Dirichlet kernel
D n
is defined by
One can show [, p. 71, Exercise 1.1] that

Math.text: (norm@(D _ n)) _ 1 = (4 / pi ^ 2) cdot logarithm@(n) + O * 1

para.p:
(On the other hand, it can quickly be seen that

Pólya and Szegő [, Part VI] present various problems about trigonometric polynomials together with solutions to them. A result on
L ∞
norms of trigonometric polynomials that Pólya and Szegő present is for the sum
=
⁢
A n
( t )
∑
= k 1
n
sin
⁢ k t
k
. The local maxima and local minima of
A n
can be explicitly determined [, p. 74, no. 23], and it can be shown that [, p. 74, no. 25]

Math.text: (norm@(A _ n)) _ infinity similar-to ((integral _ 0) ^ pi)@((sine@(t) / t) * differential-d@(t))

para.p:
If
1 ≤ p < q < ∞
, then [, p. 123, Exercise 1.8] (cf. [, p. 102, Theorem 2.6]) there is some
⁢ C
( p , q )
such that for any trigonometric polynomial
f
of degree
n
, we have

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ q less= C * open-interval@(p, q) * n ^ (1 / p - 1 / q) * (norm@(f)) _ p

para.p:
This inequality is sharp [, p. 230]: for

⁢

such that if
=

( t )

( t )
(

is called the Fejér kernel) then

Math.text: (norm@(F _ n)) _ q > C ^ prime * open-interval@(p, q) * n ^ (1 / p - 1 / q) * (norm@(F _ n)) _ p

Bernstein’s inequality [, p. 50, Exercise 7.16] states that for
1 ≤ p ≤ ∞
, if
f
is a trigonometric polynomial of degree
n
, then

Math.text: (norm@(f ^ prime)) _ p less= n * (norm@(f)) _ p

para.p:
In the other direction, if
∈ f
C 1
then

Math.text: (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * s * differential-d@(s)) + (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(s * f ^ prime * s * differential-d@(s)) + (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ t) ^ (2 * pi))@((s - 2 * pi) * f ^ prime * s * differential-d@(s)) = ((1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * s * differential-d@(s)) + (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(s * f ^ prime * s * differential-d@(s))) - ((integral _ t) ^ (2 * pi))@(f ^ prime * s * differential-d@(s)) = ((1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * s * differential-d@(s)) + evaluated-at@((1 / (2 * pi)) * s * f * s, 0, 2 * pi)) - (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * s * differential-d@(s)) - evaluated-at@(f * s, t, 2 * pi) = f * t

para.p: Hence

Math.text: absolute-value@(f * t) less= (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(absolute-value@(f * s) * differential-d@(s)) + (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(s * absolute-value@(f ^ prime * s) * differential-d@(s)) + (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ t) ^ (2 * pi))@((2 * pi - s) * absolute-value@(f ^ prime * s) * differential-d@(s)) less= (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(absolute-value@(f * s) * differential-d@(s)) + ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(absolute-value@(f ^ prime * s) * differential-d@(s)) + ((integral _ t) ^ (2 * pi))@(absolute-value@(f ^ prime * s) * differential-d@(s)) = (norm@(f)) _ 1 + 2 * pi * (norm@(f ^ prime)) _ 1
absolute-value@(f * t)

(1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(absolute-value@(f * s) * differential-d@(s)) + (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(s * absolute-value@(f ^ prime * s) * differential-d@(s)) + (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ t) ^ (2 * pi))@((2 * pi - s) * absolute-value@(f ^ prime * s) * differential-d@(s))

(1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(absolute-value@(f * s) * differential-d@(s)) + ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(absolute-value@(f ^ prime * s) * differential-d@(s)) + ((integral _ t) ^ (2 * pi))@(absolute-value@(f ^ prime * s) * differential-d@(s))
(norm@(f)) _ 1 + 2 * pi * (norm@(f ^ prime)) _ 1

para.p: so

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ infinity less= (norm@(f)) _ 1 + 2 * pi * (norm@(f ^ prime)) _ 1

para.p: This is an instance of the Sobolev inequality [].

It turns out that for a trigonometric polynomial the mass cannot be too concentrated. More precisely, the number of nonzero terms of a trigonometric polynomial restricts how concentrated its mass can be. Let
=
⁢ d μ
⁢ d t
⁢ 2 π
. Thus
=
⁢ μ
(
[ 0 ,
⁢ 2 π
]
)
1
. A result of Turán [, p. 89, Lemma 1] states that if
∈
λ 1
, … ,
λ N
Z
and
=
⁢ T
( t )
∑
= n 1
N
⁢
b n
e
⁢ i
λ n
t
,
∈
b n
C
, then for any closed arc
⊂ I
[ 0 ,
⁢ 2 π
]
,

Math.text: (norm@(T)) _ infinity less= ((2 * e) / (mu * I)) ^ (N - 1) * (maximum _ (t element-of I))@(absolute-value@(T * t))

para.p:
Nazarov [, p. 452] shows that there is some constant
A
such that if
E
is a closed subset of
[ 0 ,
⁢ 2 π
]
(not necessarily an arc), then

Math.text: (norm@(hat@(T))) _ 1 less= (A / (mu * E)) ^ N * (maximum _ (t element-of E))@(absolute-value@(f * T))

para.p:
Nazarov [] proves that there exists some constant
C
such that if
0 ≤ q ≤ 2
and
≥
⁢ μ
( E )
1 3
, then

Math.text: (norm@(T)) _ q less= e ^ (C * (N - 1) * (1 - (mu * E) / (2 * pi))) * ((1 / (2 * pi)) * (integral _ E)@((absolute-value@(T * t)) ^ q * differential-d@(t))) ^ (1 / q)

para.p: These results of Turan and Nazarov are examples of the uncertainty principle [], which is the general principle that a constrain on the support of the Fourier transform of a function constrains the support of the function itself.

. Hardy and Littlewood state the result [, p. 164, Theorem 2] that if

para.p:
A proof of this is given in Zygmund [, vol. II, p. 128, chap. XII, Theorem 6.3]. Asking if this inequality holds for
= p 1
suggests the following question that Hardy and Littlewood pose at the end of their paper [, p. 168]: Is there a constant
A
such that for all distinct positive integers
=
m k
, k
1
,
… , N
, we have

Math.text: (norm@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(cosine@(m _ k * t)))) _ 1 > A * logarithm@(N * ?)

para.p:
McGehee, Pigno and Smith [] prove that there is some
K
such that for all
N
, if
n 1
, … ,
n N
are distinct integers and
∈
c 1

C

≥
|

1
, then

Math.text: (norm@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(c _ k * e ^ (i * n _ k * t)))) _ 1 > K * logarithm@(N)

para.p: Thus

Math.text: (norm@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(cosine@(m _ k * t)))) _ 1 = (1 / 2) cdot (norm@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(e ^ (i * m _ k * t)) + e ^ (- i * m _ k * t))) _ 1 >= ((1 / 2) cdot K) * logarithm@(2 * N)

Math.text: (norm@(T _ N)) _ (2 ^ k) = O * N ^ ((1 - k / 2 ^ k) + epsilon)

para.p: Hua’s lemma is used in additive number theory. The number of sets of integer solutions of the equation

Math.text: formulae@(f * vector@(x _ 1, ldots, x _ n) = N, a _ r less= x _ r less= b _ r)

para.p: is equal to (cf. [, p. 151])

Math.text: (sum _ (a _ 1 less= x _ 1 less= b _ 1))@(cdots * (sum _ (a _ n less= x _ n less= b _ n))@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(e ^ (2 * pi * i * (f * vector@(x _ 1, ldots, x _ n) - N) * t) * differential-d@(t))))

para.p:
Borwein and Lockhart []: what is the expected
L p
norm of a trigonometric polynomial of order
n
? Kahane [, Chapter 6] also presents material on random trigonometric polynomials.

Nursultanov and Tikhonov []: the sup on a subset of
T
of a trigonometric polynomial
f
of degree
n
being lower bounded in terms of
∥ f ∥

n

For a
⁢ 2 π
-periodic function
f

:

by

Math.text: hat@(f) * k = (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (- i * k * t) * f * t * differential-d@(t))

For

ℓ p
norm of
^ f

Math.text: (norm@(hat@(f))) _ p = (((sum _ (k = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@((absolute-value@(hat@(f) * k)) ^ p)) ^ (1 / p)

para.p:
and we define the
ℓ ∞
norm of
^ f
by

Math.text: (norm@(hat@(f))) _ infinity = (maximum _ (k element-of Z))@(absolute-value@(hat@(f) * k))

para.p:
Parseval’s identity [, p. 80, Theorem 1.3] states that
=

2

∥
2
.

If
1 ≤ p < ∞
, then

Math.text: (norm@(hat@(f))) _ infinity less= (cdots + ((norm@(hat@(f))) _ infinity) ^ p + cdots) ^ (1 / p) = (norm@(hat@(f))) _ p

para.p:
If
1 ≤ p < q < ∞
, then, since for each
k
,
≤
|
⁢

|

q
1
,

Math.text: 1 = (((sum _ (k = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@((absolute-value@(hat@(f) * k) / (norm@(hat@(f))) _ q) ^ q)) ^ (1 / q) less= (((sum _ (k = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@((absolute-value@(hat@(f) * k) / (norm@(hat@(f))) _ q) ^ p)) ^ (1 / q) = ((norm@(hat@(f))) _ p) ^ (p / q) / ((norm@(hat@(f))) _ q) ^ (p / q)

para.p:
Hence for
1 ≤ p < p ≤ ∞
,

Math.text: (norm@(hat@(f))) _ q less= (norm@(hat@(f))) _ p

para.p:
For
1 ≤ p < ∞
, if
f
is a trigonometric polynomial of degree
n
then

Math.text: (norm@(hat@(f))) _ p = (((sum _ (k = - n)) ^ n)@((absolute-value@(hat@(f) * k)) ^ p)) ^ (1 / p) less= (((sum _ (k = - n)) ^ n)@(((norm@(hat@(f))) _ infinity) ^ p)) ^ (1 / p) = (2 * n + 1) ^ (1 / p) * (norm@(hat@(f))) _ infinity

para.p:
For
1 ≤ p < q < ∞
, we have [, p. 123, Problem 8.3] (this is Jensen’s inequality for sums)

Math.text: (((sum _ (k = - n)) ^ n)@((1 / (2 * n + 1)) * (absolute-value@(hat@(f) * k)) ^ p)) ^ (1 / p) less= (((sum _ (k = - n)) ^ n)@((1 / (2 * n + 1)) * (absolute-value@(hat@(f) * k)) ^ q)) ^ (1 / q)

para.p: i.e.

Hence for
1 < p < q < ∞
,

Math.text: (norm@(hat@(f))) _ p less= (2 * n + 1) ^ (1 / p - 1 / q) * (norm@(hat@(f))) _ q

para.p:
For any
t
,

Math.text: absolute-value@(f * t) = absolute-value@(((sum _ (k = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@(hat@(f) * k * e ^ (i * k * t))) less= ((sum _ (k = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@(absolute-value@(hat@(f) * k * e ^ (i * k * t))) = ((sum _ (k = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@(absolute-value@(hat@(f) * k)) = (norm@(hat@(f))) _ 1

para.p: Hence

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ infinity less= (norm@(hat@(f))) _ 1

para.p:
For any
∈ k Z
,

Math.text: absolute-value@(hat@(f) * k) = absolute-value@((1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (- i * k * t) * f * t * differential-d@(t))) less= (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(absolute-value@(f * t) * differential-d@(t)) = (norm@(f)) _ 1

para.p: Hence

Math.text: (norm@(hat@(f))) _ infinity less= (norm@(f)) _ 1

para.p:
The Hausdorff-Young inequality [, p. 57, Corollary 2.4] states that for
1 ≤ p ≤ 2
and
=
+
1 p
1 q
1
, if
∈ f
L p
then

Math.text: (norm@(hat@(f))) _ q less= (norm@(f)) _ p

para.p:
The dual Hausdorff-Young inequality [, p. 58, Corollary 2.5] states that for
1 ≤ p ≤ 2
and
=
+
1 p
1 q
1
, if
∈ f
L q
then

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ q less= (norm@(hat@(f))) _ q

para.p: A survey on the Hausdorff-Young inequality is given in [])

para.p:
where
=
∥ t ∥
min k
|
- t k
|
is the distance from
t
to a nearest integer. The large sieve [] is an inequality of the form

Math.text: ((sum _ (r = 1)) ^ R)@((absolute-value@(S * 2 * pi * t _ r)) ^ 2) less= Delta * open-interval@(N, delta) * ((sum _ (k = M + 1)) ^ (M + N))@((absolute-value@(a _ k)) ^ 2)

para.p:
A result of Selberg [, p. 559, Theorem 3] shows that the large sieve is valid for
= Δ
+
- N 1
δ
- 1
.
Kristiansen []
Boas []

For
: F
→
/ Z n
C
, its Fourier transform
:
^ F
→
/ Z n
C
(called the discrete Fourier transform) is defined by

Math.text: formulae@(hat@(F) * k = (1 / n) * ((sum _ (j = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@(F * j * e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * j * k) / n)), 0 less= k less= n - 1)

para.p: and one can prove [, p. 223, Theorem 1.2] that

Math.text: formulae@(F * j = ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@(hat@(F) * k * e ^ ((2 * pi * i * k * j) / N)), 0 less= j less= n - 1)

para.p:
One can also prove Parseval’s identity for the Fourier transform on
/ Z n
[, p. 223, Theorem 1.2]. It states

Math.text: ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@((absolute-value@(hat@(F) * k)) ^ 2) = (1 / n) * ((sum _ (j = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@((absolute-value@(F * j)) ^ 2)

The Marcinkiewicz-Zygmund inequalities [, vol. II, p. 28, chap. X, Theorem 7.5] state that there is a constant
A
such that for
1 ≤ p ≤ ∞
, if
f

n

and for each

A p

n

Máté and Nevai [, p. 148, Theorem 6] prove that for
> p 0
, if
S n
is a trigonometric polynomial of degree
n
then

Math.text: (norm@(S _ n)) _ infinity less= (((1 + n * p) * e) / 2) ^ (1 / p) * (norm@(S _ n)) _ p

para.p:
Máté and Nevai [] prove a version of Bernstein’s inequality for
0 < p < 1
, and their result can be sharpened to the following []: For
0 < p < 1
, if
T n
is a trigonometric polynomial of order
n
then

Math.text: (norm@((T _ n) ^ prime)) _ p less= n * (norm@(T _ n)) _ p

para.p:
Let
=
supp
^ f
{
∈ k Z
:
≠
⁢
^ f
( k )
0
}
. A subset
Λ
of
Z
is called a Sidon set [, p. 121, §5.7.2] if there exists a constant
B
such that for every trigonometric polynomial
f
with
⊆
supp
^ f
Λ
we have

Math.text: (norm@(hat@(f))) _ 1 less= B * (norm@(f)) _ infinity

para.p:
Let
⁢ B
( Λ )
be the least such
B
. A sequence of positive integers
λ k
is said to be lacunary if there is a constant
ρ
such that
>
λ
+ k 1
⁢ ρ
λ k
for all
k
. If
λ k
is a lacunary sequence, then
{
λ k
}
is a Sidon set [, p. 154, Corollary 6.17]. If
⊂ Λ Z
is a Sidon set, then [, p. 128, Theorem 5.7.7] (cf. [, p. 157, Corollary 6.19]) for any
2 < p < ∞
, for every trigonometric polynomial
f
with
⊆
supp
^ f
Λ
we have

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ p less= B * Lambda * square-root@(p) * (norm@(f)) _ 2

para.p: and

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ 2 less= 2 * B * Lambda * (norm@(f)) _ 1

para.p:
Let
0 < p < ∞
. A subset
E
of
Z
is called a
⁢ Λ
( p )
-set if for every
0 < r < p
there is some
⁢ A
( E , p )
such that for all trigonometric polynomials
f
with
⊂
supp
^ f
E
we have

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ p less= A * open-interval@(E, p) * (norm@(f)) _ 2

para.p:
⁢ Λ
( p )
sets were introduced by Rudin, and he discusses them in his autobiography [, Chapter 28]. A modern survey of
⁢ Λ
( p )
-sets is given by Bourgain [].

Bochkarev [] proves various lower bounds on the
L 1
norms of certain trigonometric polynomials. Let
∈
c k
C
,
≥ k 1
. If there are constants
A
and
B
such that

Math.text: formulae@(A * ((logarithm@(k)) ^ s / square-root@(k)) less= absolute-value@(c _ k) less= B * ((logarithm@(k)) ^ s / square-root@(k)), k >= 1)

para.p: then [, p. 58, Theorem 19]

Math.text: (norm@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(c _ k * e ^ (i * k ^ 2 * t)))) _ 1 >> cases@((logarithm@(n)) ^ (s - 1 / 2), s > 1 / 2, logarithm@(logarithm@(n)), s = 1 / 2)

Math.text: (norm@(P)) _ 1 = (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((1 cdot absolute-value@(P * t)) * differential-d@(t)) less= (norm@(1)) _ 2 cdot (norm@(P)) _ 2 = 1 cdot (norm@(hat@(P))) _ 2 = square-root@(n + 1)

para.p: Newman [] shows that in fact we can do better than what we get using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and Parseval’s identity:

Math.text: (norm@(P)) _ 1 less square-root@(n + 0.97)
